articles.headline: June Sales at Ford Fall Less Than G.M. or Chrysler
articles.snippet: June sales figures showed another difficult month for some automakers, yet provided a hint that demand for new vehicles in the U.S. might finally be on the upswing.
articles.abstract: June sales figures showed another difficult month for some automakers, yet provided a hint that demand for new vehicles in the U.S. might finally be on the upswing.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Automakers had another difficult month in June, but sales figures released Wednesday included faint glimmers of hope for the industry.

articles.headline: In Refugee Aid, Pakistan’s War Has New Front
articles.snippet: Hard-line Islamist charities are using a refugee crisis to sour public opinion about the United States.
articles.abstract: Hard-line Islamist charities are using a refugee crisis to sour public opinion about the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: QASIM PULA, Pakistan  Islamist charities and the United States are competing for the allegiance of the two million people displaced by the fight against the Taliban in Swat and other parts of Pakistan  and so far, the Islamists are in the lead.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Pir Zubair Shah

articles.headline: A Router So Complete, and Vexing
articles.snippet: From D-Link comes a device that offers virtually every home router feature you can think of, and then some. Too bad it’s so user-unfriendly.
articles.abstract: From D-Link comes a device that offers virtually every home router feature you can think of, and then some. Too bad it’s so user-unfriendly.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before someone coined the term “mashup,” mashups were popular in the technology world. Some are made in heaven, and are now standard pairings: clock+radio, refrigerator+freezer, cellphone+camera.

articles.headline: Bank Fees Rise as Lenders Try to Offset Losses
articles.snippet: Some institutions quietly and creatively charge people more to save and spend their own money.
articles.abstract: Some institutions quietly and creatively charge people more to save and spend their own money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bounced check: $32. Stop-payment: $30. A.T.M. charge: as high as $3.

articles.headline: Finding Debt a Bigger Hurdle Than Bar Exam
articles.snippet: Robert Bowman, an aspiring lawyer, was refused entry to the New York bar because of $400,000 in student debt.
articles.abstract: Robert Bowman, an aspiring lawyer, was refused entry to the New York bar because of $400,000 in student debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: All his life, Robert Bowman wanted to be a lawyer. He overcame a troubled childhood, a tragic accident that nearly cost him a leg and a debilitating Jet Ski collision.

articles.headline: U.S. Marines Try to Retake Afghan Valley From Taliban
articles.snippet: Almost 4,000 U.S. Marines moved to clear insurgents from the hotly contested Helmand River valley before the nation’s Aug. 20 presidential election.
articles.abstract: Almost 4,000 U.S. Marines moved to clear insurgents from the hotly contested Helmand River valley before the nation’s Aug. 20 presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Almost 4,000 United States Marines, backed by helicopter gunships, pushed into the volatile Helmand River valley in southwestern Afghanistan early Thursday morning to try to take back the region from Taliban fighters whose control of poppy harvests and opium smuggling in Helmand provides major financing for the Afghan insurgency.

articles.headline: Risk Cuts at Morgan May Lead to a Loss
articles.snippet: Late last year, after the financial crisis, Morgan Stanley made a decision that its biggest rivals avoided: burned by the crisis, it would take far fewer risks in its trading.
articles.abstract: Late last year, after the financial crisis, Morgan Stanley made a decision that its biggest rivals avoided: burned by the crisis, it would take far fewer risks in its trading.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last year, after the financial crisis, Morgan Stanley made a decision that its biggest rivals avoided: burned by the crisis, it would take far fewer risks in its trading.

articles.headline: For an Insider, a Lonely Road to Senate Run
articles.snippet: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a quintessential New York liberal, is fighting an uphill battle for the seat held by Kirsten E. Gillibrand.
articles.abstract: Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a quintessential New York liberal, is fighting an uphill battle for the seat held by Kirsten E. Gillibrand.
articles.lead_paragraph: The conversation was not going well. Dennis Mehiel, the powerful Democratic fund-raiser, had Representative Carolyn B. Maloney on the line. And she was obviously unhappy.

articles.headline: U.S. Nuns Facing Vatican Scrutiny
articles.snippet: The Vatican is quietly conducting two sweeping investigations of American nuns, leaving some fearful that they are the targets of a doctrinal inquisition.
articles.abstract: The Vatican is quietly conducting two sweeping investigations of American nuns, leaving some fearful that they are the targets of a doctrinal inquisition.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Vatican is quietly conducting two sweeping investigations of American nuns, a development that has startled and dismayed nuns who fear they are the targets of a doctrinal inquisition.

articles.headline: Markets Fall After Jobs Report
articles.snippet: Wall Street ended the week with a sharp decline, spurred by the June jobless report. The Dow fell by more than 220 points.
articles.abstract: Wall Street ended the week with a sharp decline, spurred by the June jobless report. The Dow fell by more than 220 points.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fears that rising unemployment will prolong what is already a deep, painful recession sent stocks tumbling on Thursday and pushed the broad market into the red once again for the year.

articles.headline: Joblessness Hits 9.5%, Deflating Recovery Hopes
articles.snippet: The pace of job losses quickened last month with the American economy shedding 467,000 jobs, as unemployment rose to its highest level in 26 years.
articles.abstract: The pace of job losses quickened last month with the American economy shedding 467,000 jobs, as unemployment rose to its highest level in 26 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy lost 467,000 more jobs in June, and the unemployment rate edged up to 9.5 percent in a sobering indication that the longest recession since the 1930s had yet to release its hold.
